canonical_explanation.text: A wave is a disturbance that transfers energy from one point to another without the transfer of matter. Waves are classified as transverse (particle displacement perpendicular to wave propagation, e.g., waves on a string, light) or longitudinal (particle displacement along propagation, e.g., sound waves). A progressive wave is described by y = A sin(kx − ωt), where A is amplitude, k = 2π/λ is the wave number, ω = 2πf is angular frequency, and the wave speed v = fλ = ω/k. The superposition principle states that when two or more waves overlap, the resultant displacement is the algebraic sum of individual displacements. Interference occurs when two waves of similar frequency overlap: constructive interference when they are in phase and destructive when out of phase. Standing waves form when two identical waves travel in opposite directions, creating nodes (zero displacement) and antinodes (maximum displacement). The speed of sound in a gas is v = √(γP/ρ), and increases with temperature. Vibrations of strings produce harmonics with frequencies fₙ = n/(2L)√(T/μ); open pipes produce all harmonics fₙ = nv/(2L) while closed pipes produce only odd harmonics fₙ = nv/(4L) (n = 1, 3, 5...). Beats occur when two waves of slightly different frequencies interfere, producing a periodic variation in loudness with beat frequency f_beat = |f₁ − f₂|. The Doppler effect describes the apparent change in frequency when source or observer moves relative to the medium.
rules: Wave equation: y = A sin(kx − ωt); wave speed v = fλ = ω/k; speed on a string v = √(T/μ).
Superposition principle: The net displacement at any point is the algebraic sum of displacements due to individual waves.
Standing waves on a string: fₙ = n/(2L)√(T/μ); nodes are separated by λ/2.
Open pipe harmonics: fₙ = nv/(2L) for n = 1, 2, 3...; closed pipe: fₙ = nv/(4L) for n = 1, 3, 5... (odd only).
Doppler effect: f' = f(v ± v_o)/(v ∓ v_s), where upper signs apply when source and observer approach each other.

questions.question_text: Sound waves in air are:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound waves in air are longitudinal waves because the particles in the medium (air) move back and forth in the same direction as the wave propagation, rather than perpendicular to it like in transverse waves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound waves are not transverse waves because the particles in the medium (air) do not move perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation. They are also not electromagnetic waves, which are waves of oscillating electric and magnetic fields. Sound waves in air are longitudinal waves, where the particles move back and forth in the same direction as the wave.

questions.question_text: The relation between wave speed (v), frequency (f) and wavelength (λ) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B, v = fλ, because this is the fundamental equation that relates the speed of a wave (v), its frequency (f), and its wavelength (λ). This equation captures the key physical principle that the speed of a wave is equal to the product of its frequency and wavelength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately capture the relationship between wave speed, frequency, and wavelength. Option A, v = f/λ, is incorrect because it has the variables inverted. Option C, v = λ/f, is also incorrect because it has the variables inverted. Option D, v = f²λ, is incorrect because the wave speed is not proportional to the square of the frequency times the wavelength.

questions.question_text: In a transverse wave, the particles of the medium vibrate:

options.text: Along the direction of wave propagation
Perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation

questions.explanation_correct: In a transverse wave, the particles of the medium vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation. This is because the wave energy is transmitted perpendicular to the oscillation of the particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a transverse wave, the particles of the medium do not vibrate along the direction of wave propagation. This would be the case for a longitudinal wave, where the particles oscillate parallel to the direction of wave travel. Transverse waves also do not have particles vibrating in circular paths or randomly in all directions.

questions.question_text: A wave has the equation y = 0.02 sin(100πt − 2πx) m. Its frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The given wave equation is y = 0.02 sin(100πt - 2πx) m. The angular frequency ω = 100π rad/s, and the frequency f = ω/2π = 50 Hz. Therefore, the correct answer is B) 50 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the angular frequency given in the wave equation. Option A) 100 Hz has double the angular frequency, option C) 200 Hz has four times the angular frequency, and option D) 2 Hz has one-twenty-fifth the angular frequency. The correct frequency is 50 Hz, which is obtained by dividing the angular frequency of 100π rad/s by 2π.

questions.question_text: For the wave y = 0.02 sin(100πt − 2πx) m, the wavelength is:
questions.explanation_correct: The wavelength of a wave is given by the formula λ = 2π/k, where k is the wave number. In the given wave equation, k = 2π/2 = 1, so the wavelength is λ = 2π/1 = 2 m, which corresponds to option B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly represent the wavelength of the given wave. Option A, 0.5 m, is half the correct value, while option D, π m, does not match the formula for wavelength. Option C, 2 m, correctly represents the wavelength based on the wave equation provided.

questions.question_text: The speed of a transverse wave on a string of mass per unit length 0.01 kg/m under a tension of 100 N is:
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of a transverse wave on a string is given by the formula v = √(T/μ), where T is the tension in the string and μ is the mass per unit length. Plugging in the values, we get v = √(100 N / 0.01 kg/m) = 100 m/s, which matches option B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The speed of a transverse wave on a string is not 10 m/s (option A), 1000 m/s (option C), or 50 m/s (option D). The correct formula to calculate the wave speed is v = √(T/μ), where T is the tension and μ is the mass per unit length of the string. Substituting the given values, we get v = √(100 N / 0.01 kg/m) = 100 m/s, which matches option B.

questions.question_text: The principle of superposition states that when two waves overlap, the resultant displacement is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The principle of superposition states that when two or more waves overlap, the resultant displacement is the algebraic sum of the individual displacements. This means the final wave shape is obtained by adding up the individual wave shapes at each point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The principle of superposition does not state that the resultant displacement is the product, average, or difference of the individual displacements. This is because the resultant wave is formed by the linear addition of the individual waves, not by any other mathematical operation. The correct answer is that the resultant displacement is the algebraic sum of the individual displacements.

questions.question_text: In a standing wave, the points of zero displacement are called:
questions.explanation_correct: In a standing wave, the points of zero displacement are called nodes. This is because at these points, the wave crests and troughs of the two interfering waves cancel out, resulting in no net displacement of the medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The points of maximum displacement in a standing wave are called antinodes. Nodes are the points where the displacement is zero, as the crests and troughs of the two interfering waves cancel each other out at these locations. The crests and troughs of the wave are not called nodes in a standing wave pattern.

questions.question_text: The distance between two consecutive nodes in a standing wave is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a standing wave, the distance between two consecutive nodes (points of zero displacement) is half the wavelength (λ/2). This is because the standing wave is formed by the interference of two waves traveling in opposite directions, and the nodes occur at the points where the waves are perfectly out of phase, cancelling each other out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is option B, λ/2. This is because in a standing wave, the distance between two consecutive nodes (points of zero displacement) is half the wavelength. The other options do not correctly describe the distance between nodes in a standing wave. Option A, λ, would be the distance between two consecutive crests or troughs, which is the full wavelength. Option C, λ/4, would be the distance between a node and an antinode (point of maximum displacement), not between two nodes. Option D, 2λ, is double the wavelength and does not represent the distance between nodes.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in a gas is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound in a gas is given by the formula v = √(γP/ρ), where γ is the ratio of specific heats, P is the pressure, and ρ is the density of the gas. This formula takes into account the compressibility of the gas, which affects the speed of sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B, v = √(γP/ρ), is the correct formula for the speed of sound in a gas. Option A, v = √(P/ρ), is incorrect because it does not consider the compressibility of the gas, which is an important factor in determining the speed of sound. Option C, v = P/ρ, is incorrect because it does not have the square root term, and option D, v = γP/ρ, is incorrect because it does not have the square root term either.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in air at 0°C is 332 m/s. At 100°C, the speed is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound in air increases with temperature. At 100°C, the temperature is 100 degrees higher than 0°C, so the speed of sound will be higher by the square root of the ratio of the absolute temperatures, which is approximately 387 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B, 387 m/s, is the correct answer. The speed of sound in air is given by the formula v = √(γP/ρ), where γ is the specific heat ratio, P is the pressure, and ρ is the density of air. As the temperature increases, the density of air decreases, causing the speed of sound to increase. Therefore, at 100°C, the speed of sound will be higher than the 332 m/s at 0°C.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound is generally greatest in:
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound is generally greatest in solids because the particles in solids are tightly packed and have strong intermolecular forces, allowing for faster transmission of sound waves compared to gases and liquids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The speed of sound is not greatest in gases, liquids, or a vacuum. Gases and liquids have weaker intermolecular forces, so sound waves travel slower in them compared to solids. In a vacuum, there are no particles for the sound waves to travel through, so sound cannot propagate at all.

questions.question_text: The fundamental frequency of a string of length L, tension T and mass per unit length μ is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A because the fundamental frequency of a string is given by the formula f = 1/(2L)√(T/μ), where L is the length of the string, T is the tension, and μ is the mass per unit length of the string.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A. Option B is incorrect because the formula for the fundamental frequency is 1/(2L)√(T/μ), not 1/L√(T/μ). Option C is incorrect because the formula does not involve 2L. Option D is incorrect because the formula involves the square root of T/μ, not μ/T.

questions.question_text: A string of length 1 m and mass per unit length 0.01 kg/m is under tension 40 N. Its fundamental frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 31.6 Hz. This can be calculated using the formula for the fundamental frequency of a string under tension: f = (1/2L)√(T/μ), where L is the length of the string, T is the tension, and μ is the mass per unit length. Plugging in the given values, we get f = (1/2 × 1)√(40/0.01) = 31.6 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the formula for the fundamental frequency of a string under tension. Option A) 10 Hz is too low, option B) 20 Hz is too low, and option D) 100 Hz is too high. The correct formula and values must be used to arrive at the right answer of 31.6 Hz.

questions.question_text: An open pipe of length 0.5 m produces its fundamental frequency. If the speed of sound is 340 m/s, this frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 340 Hz. For an open pipe, the fundamental frequency is given by f = v/(2L), where v is the speed of sound and L is the length of the pipe. With a length of 0.5 m and a speed of sound of 340 m/s, the fundamental frequency is 340 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the formula for the fundamental frequency of an open pipe. Option A) 170 Hz is half the correct frequency, Option C) 680 Hz is double the correct frequency, and Option D) 85 Hz is not derived from the given information.

questions.question_text: A closed pipe of length 1 m produces its fundamental frequency. If the speed of sound is 340 m/s, this frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 85 Hz. For a closed pipe, the fundamental frequency is given by f = v/(4L), where v is the speed of sound and L is the length of the pipe. With v = 340 m/s and L = 1 m, the fundamental frequency is 340/(4 × 1) = 85 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options B) 170 Hz, C) 340 Hz, and D) 42.5 Hz are not correct. Option B) is twice the fundamental frequency, C) is the speed of sound, and D) is half the fundamental frequency. The correct answer is A) 85 Hz, which is the fundamental frequency calculated using the formula f = v/(4L) for a closed pipe of length 1 m with a speed of sound of 340 m/s.

questions.question_text: A closed pipe can produce which harmonics?
questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe can only produce odd harmonics (1st, 3rd, 5th, etc.) because the particles at the closed ends have zero displacement, creating nodes that only allow standing waves with antinodes at the open ends. This results in the closed pipe producing only the odd harmonics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that a closed pipe can produce only the odd harmonics, not all harmonics. This is because the closed ends of the pipe act as nodes, where the displacement of the particles is zero. This means that only the odd harmonics, where the antinodes align with the open ends of the pipe, can be produced. The even harmonics cannot be produced in a closed pipe.

questions.question_text: The beat frequency produced by two tuning forks of frequencies 256 Hz and 260 Hz is:
questions.explanation_correct: The beat frequency is the difference between the two frequencies. Since the frequencies are 256 Hz and 260 Hz, the beat frequency is 4 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) 4 Hz. The beat frequency is produced when two waves with slightly different frequencies interfere. The frequency difference between the two tuning forks is 260 Hz - 256 Hz = 4 Hz, which is the beat frequency.

questions.question_text: The Doppler effect in sound refers to the apparent change in:
questions.explanation_correct: The Doppler effect refers to the apparent change in frequency of a wave when the source or observer is moving relative to the medium. This is because the frequency of the wave perceived by the observer is different from the frequency emitted by the source. Therefore, the Doppler effect in sound refers to the apparent change in frequency, not amplitude or speed of sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Doppler effect does not refer to changes in the amplitude or speed of sound. The speed of sound in a medium is a fundamental property and is not affected by the motion of the source or observer. The Doppler effect only causes an apparent change in the frequency of the sound wave, which is perceived by the observer as the source or observer moves relative to the medium.

questions.question_text: A source of frequency 500 Hz moves towards a stationary observer at 20 m/s. The apparent frequency heard by the observer is (speed of sound = 340 m/s):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 531.25 Hz. This is because the Doppler effect causes the frequency heard by the observer to be higher than the original frequency of the source, due to the source moving towards the observer. The formula for the Doppler shift is f' = f(v + v_s)/(v - v_r), where f' is the observed frequency, f is the source frequency, v is the speed of sound, v_s is the source velocity, and v_r is the receiver velocity. Plugging in the values, we get f' = 500 Hz * (340 m/s + 20 m/s)/(340 m/s - 0 m/s) = 531.25 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers B) 470.6 Hz, C) 500 Hz, and D) 550 Hz are not correct. The Doppler effect causes the observed frequency to be higher than the original frequency when the source is moving towards the observer. The correct formula and calculation shows that the observed frequency is 531.25 Hz, not any of the other options provided.

questions.question_text: An observer moves towards a stationary source of frequency 400 Hz at 34 m/s. The apparent frequency is (v = 340 m/s):
questions.explanation_correct: The apparent frequency is higher than the original frequency due to the Doppler effect. When the observer moves towards the stationary source, the wavelength of the sound waves becomes shorter, resulting in an increase in the observed frequency to 440 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A, 440 Hz. When an observer moves towards a stationary source, the apparent frequency increases due to the Doppler effect. The formula for the Doppler shift is f' = f * (v + v_o) / (v - v_s), where f' is the apparent frequency, f is the original frequency, v is the speed of sound, v_o is the observer's speed, and v_s is the source's speed. Plugging in the values, we get f' = 400 * (340 + 34) / (340 - 0) = 440 Hz.

questions.question_text: A wave y = 0.05 sin(πx − 4πt) m is travelling along a string. The wave speed is:
questions.explanation_correct: The wave speed is given by the formula v = ω/k, where ω is the angular frequency and k is the wave number. In the given equation, ω = 4π rad/s and k = π m^-1, so the wave speed is v = ω/k = 4 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options B) π m/s and C) 4π m/s do not match the formula for wave speed. Option D) 0.25 m/s is incorrect because the wave speed is directly given in the question as 4 m/s.

questions.question_text: In a standing wave, the energy is:

options.text: Confined between two consecutive nodes; there is no net transfer of energy

questions.explanation_correct: In a standing wave, the energy is confined between two consecutive nodes and there is no net transfer of energy along the string. This is because the incident and reflected waves interfere to create a standing wave pattern with fixed points of maximum and minimum displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The energy in a standing wave is not transmitted continuously along the string, nor is it concentrated only at the nodes. The energy is instead confined between consecutive nodes, with no net transfer of energy along the string. This is because the incident and reflected waves interfere to create a standing wave pattern with fixed points of maximum and minimum displacement.

questions.question_text: If the tension in a sonometer wire is quadrupled, the fundamental frequency becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental frequency of a sonometer wire is inversely proportional to the square root of the tension. Since the tension is quadrupled, the fundamental frequency becomes two times the original value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the tension is quadrupled, the frequency does not become four times the original value. The fundamental frequency is proportional to the square root of the tension, so quadrupling the tension would double the frequency.

questions.question_text: A source and observer move towards each other, each at 17 m/s. The source frequency is 500 Hz and speed of sound is 340 m/s. The apparent frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 552.6 Hz. When the source and observer are moving towards each other, the apparent frequency increases due to the Doppler effect. The formula for the Doppler shift is f' = f(v+v_o)/(v-v_s), where f' is the apparent frequency, f is the source frequency, v is the speed of sound, v_o is the observer's speed, and v_s is the source's speed. Plugging in the given values, we get f' = 500 Hz * (340 m/s + 17 m/s)/(340 m/s - 17 m/s) = 552.6 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not account for the Doppler effect. Option B) 500 Hz is the original source frequency without any Doppler shift. Option C) 450 Hz is the apparent frequency if the source and observer were moving away from each other. Option D) 600 Hz is incorrect because it exceeds the maximum possible Doppler shift given the relative speeds and sound speed.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in air at temperature T (in kelvin) is related to its speed at 273 K by:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B, v_T = v₂₇₃ × √(T/273), because the speed of sound in a gas is proportional to the square root of the absolute temperature. This means that as the temperature increases, the speed of sound also increases accordingly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not accurate. Option A, v_T = v₂₇₃ × T/273, is incorrect because the speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the absolute temperature, not the absolute temperature itself. Options C and D are also incorrect because they do not accurately represent the relationship between the speed of sound and the absolute temperature.

questions.question_text: Two waves y₁ = A sin(ωt) and y₂ = A sin(ωt + π) are superimposed. The resultant is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 0 (complete destructive interference). When two waves with the same amplitude but opposite phases (π radians out of phase) are superimposed, they completely cancel each other out, resulting in zero net displacement or destructive interference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) 0 (complete destructive interference). When two waves with the same amplitude but opposite phases (π radians out of phase) are superimposed, they completely cancel each other out, resulting in zero net displacement or destructive interference. The other options are incorrect because they do not represent the correct result of the superposition of the given waves.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the fundamental frequency of an open pipe to that of a closed pipe of the same length is:
questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental frequency of an open pipe is twice the fundamental frequency of a closed pipe of the same length. This is because an open pipe has two open ends, allowing waves to reflect off both ends, while a closed pipe has only one open end, so the wave reflects off the closed end. Therefore, the ratio of the fundamental frequencies is 2:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) 2:1. An open pipe has two open ends, allowing waves to reflect off both ends, so the fundamental frequency is twice that of a closed pipe of the same length, which has only one open end. The other options are incorrect because they do not accurately represent the relationship between the fundamental frequencies of open and closed pipes.

questions.question_text: Two tuning forks produce 5 beats per second. If one fork has frequency 440 Hz, the other has frequency:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 445 Hz or 435 Hz. Beats occur when two waves of slightly different frequencies interfere. The beat frequency is equal to the absolute difference between the two frequencies. Since the two forks produce 5 beats per second, the frequency difference between them must be 5 Hz. If one fork has a frequency of 440 Hz, the other must have a frequency of either 445 Hz or 435 Hz to create a 5 Hz difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the conditions given in the question. Option B) 445 Hz only is wrong because the other fork must have a frequency of 435 Hz to create 5 beats per second. Option C) 435 Hz only is wrong for the same reason - the other fork must have a frequency of 445 Hz. Option D) 450 Hz is wrong because the frequency difference between the two forks would be 10 Hz, not 5 Hz as stated in the question.

questions.question_text: Waves transfer:

options.text: Matter from one place to another
Energy from one place to another

questions.explanation_correct: Waves transfer energy from one place to another without transferring the actual matter itself. This is the defining characteristic of a wave - it carries energy through a medium without moving the medium's particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Waves do not transfer matter from one place to another. This is because waves are disturbances that propagate through a medium, but the medium itself does not move along with the wave. Instead, the wave transfers energy through the medium, allowing the disturbance to travel from one point to another. Therefore, option B, 'energy from one place to another', is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Humidity in air causes the speed of sound to:
questions.explanation_correct: Increasing the humidity in air increases the speed of sound. This is because water vapor has a lower density than air, and the speed of sound is higher in less dense mediums.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because the speed of sound in air increases with humidity. This is because water vapor has a lower density than air, so the presence of more water vapor makes the air less dense overall. Since the speed of sound depends on the density of the medium, a less dense air will allow sound to travel faster.

questions.question_text: A source of frequency 1000 Hz moves away from a stationary observer at 34 m/s. The apparent frequency is (v = 340 m/s):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 909 Hz. When the source moves away from the observer, the observed frequency decreases due to the Doppler effect. Using the Doppler shift formula, the observed frequency is f' = f(1 - v/c), where f is the source frequency, v is the speed of the source, and c is the speed of the wave. Plugging in the values, we get f' = 1000 Hz (1 - 34 m/s / 340 m/s) = 909 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are B) 1100 Hz, C) 1000 Hz, and D) 850 Hz. Option B) is incorrect because the observed frequency should decrease, not increase, when the source moves away. Option C) is incorrect because the observed frequency changes due to the Doppler effect. Option D) is incorrect because the calculated observed frequency is 909 Hz, not 850 Hz.

questions.question_text: If the tension in a string is doubled and the mass per unit length is halved, the wave speed becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: The wave speed on a string is given by the formula v = √(T/μ), where T is the tension and μ is the mass per unit length. If the tension is doubled and the mass per unit length is halved, the wave speed becomes 2 times the original value, as the square root of 4 (doubled tension) divided by 1/2 (halved mass per unit length) is 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the tension is doubled and the mass per unit length is halved, the wave speed does not become 4 times the original value. This is because the wave speed formula involves the square root of the ratio of tension to mass per unit length. Doubling the tension and halving the mass per unit length results in the wave speed becoming 2 times the original value, not 4 times.

questions.question_text: The second overtone of a closed pipe has a frequency of 750 Hz. The fundamental frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental frequency of a closed pipe is related to the second overtone frequency by f₂ = 3f₀, where f₀ is the fundamental frequency. Since the second overtone frequency is given as 750 Hz, the fundamental frequency can be calculated as f₀ = 750/3 = 250 Hz, which matches option A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly relate the second overtone frequency to the fundamental frequency. The fundamental frequency of a closed pipe is given by f₀ = v/(4L), where v is the speed of sound and L is the length of the pipe. Since the second overtone has a frequency of 750 Hz, the fundamental frequency can be calculated as f₀ = 750/3 = 250 Hz, which is option A.

questions.question_text: Two identical waves of amplitude A and same frequency travelling in opposite directions produce a standing wave. The maximum amplitude of the standing wave is:
questions.explanation_correct: When two identical waves travelling in opposite directions interfere, they create a standing wave. The maximum amplitude of the standing wave occurs at the antinodes, where the displacements of the two waves are added constructively, resulting in a total amplitude of 2A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The maximum amplitude of the standing wave is not equal to the individual wave amplitude A, nor is it A/2 or A√2. This is because when the two identical waves interfere, their displacements are added constructively at the antinodes, resulting in a total amplitude of 2A.

questions.question_text: Sound waves can travel through a vacuum.
questions.explanation_correct: Sound waves are a type of longitudinal wave, which require a medium (such as air, water, or a solid material) to propagate. Since a vacuum is the absence of any medium, sound waves cannot travel through a vacuum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many people may think that sound waves can travel through a vacuum because they are familiar with how sound travels through air. However, sound waves are mechanical waves that require a medium to propagate. In a vacuum, there are no particles or medium for the sound waves to travel through, so sound waves cannot travel in a vacuum.

questions.question_text: In a standing wave, the distance between a node and the nearest antinode is λ/4.
questions.explanation_correct: In a standing wave, the distance between a node (where the wave amplitude is zero) and the nearest antinode (where the wave amplitude is maximum) is indeed λ/4, where λ is the wavelength of the wave. This is because the nodes and antinodes are formed by the interference of two waves travelling in opposite directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that the distance between a node and the nearest antinode in a standing wave is half the wavelength, or λ/2. However, this is not correct. The distance between a node and the nearest antinode is actually λ/4, as the nodes and antinodes are formed by the interference of two waves travelling in opposite directions.

questions.question_text: A closed pipe produces all harmonics just like an open pipe.
questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe only produces odd harmonics (frequencies that are odd multiples of the fundamental frequency), while an open pipe can produce all harmonics (even and odd multiples of the fundamental frequency). This is because the boundary conditions are different for closed and open pipes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that closed pipes and open pipes produce the same set of harmonics. However, this is not the case. In a closed pipe, the waves reflect off the closed end, creating a node at that end. This results in the pipe only allowing waves with frequencies that are odd multiples of the fundamental frequency. Open pipes, on the other hand, can support waves with both even and odd harmonics.

questions.question_text: The Doppler effect is observed only when the source is moving; a moving observer does not experience a frequency shift.
questions.explanation_correct: The Doppler effect is observed both when the source is moving and when the observer is moving relative to the medium. In both cases, there is a change in the observed frequency of the wave due to the relative motion between the source, medium, and observer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Doppler effect occurs due to the relative motion between the wave source and the observer. This means that the Doppler effect can be observed both when the source is moving and when the observer is moving, as long as there is a relative motion between them. The frequency shift experienced by the observer is the same regardless of whether the source or the observer is moving.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in air is independent of pressure at constant temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound in air is independent of pressure at constant temperature. This is because the speed of sound in a gas depends on the bulk modulus of the gas and its density, which are both independent of pressure at constant temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The speed of sound in air is not independent of pressure at constant temperature. As the pressure increases, the density of air also increases, and this causes the speed of sound to increase as well. The formula for the speed of sound in a gas is v = √(γP/ρ), where γ is the ratio of specific heats, P is the pressure, and ρ is the density. So the speed of sound is directly proportional to the square root of the pressure.

questions.question_text: The speed of a transverse wave on a string is v = √(T/___), where the blank is the mass per unit length.
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of a transverse wave on a string is given by the formula v = √(T/μ), where T is the tension in the string and μ is the mass per unit length of the string. This is because the restoring force in a transverse wave is the tension in the string, and the inertia of the wave is determined by the mass per unit length of the string.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'μ', which represents the mass per unit length of the string. This is because the formula for the speed of a transverse wave on a string is v = √(T/μ), where T is the tension in the string. The mass per unit length, μ, determines the inertia of the wave and, along with the tension, affects the wave speed.

questions.question_text: The fundamental frequency of an open pipe of length 0.85 m is ___ Hz (speed of sound = 340 m/s).
questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental frequency of an open pipe is given by the formula f = v/(2L), where v is the speed of sound and L is the length of the pipe. Plugging in the values, we get f = 340 m/s / (2 * 0.85 m) = 200 Hz, which is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 100 Hz. This is because some students may think that the formula for the fundamental frequency of an open pipe is f = v/L, which would give 340 m/s / 0.85 m = 400 Hz. However, the correct formula is f = v/(2L), which gives 200 Hz for the given pipe length of 0.85 m.

questions.question_text: Two tuning forks produce 3 beats per second. If the frequencies are f and 253 Hz, and f > 253 Hz, then f = ___ Hz.
questions.explanation_correct: The frequency of the two tuning forks are f and 253 Hz, with f being greater than 253 Hz. Since the beats per second is 3, the difference between the frequencies is 3 Hz. Therefore, the frequency f must be 256 Hz, as 256 - 253 = 3 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, 256 Hz. However, if you calculated the frequency f incorrectly, you may have thought the answer was a different value. To get the correct answer of 256 Hz, you need to recognize that the beats per second are 3, and the higher frequency f is greater than 253 Hz. Therefore, the difference between the two frequencies must be 3 Hz, making the higher frequency f equal to 256 Hz.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in air at 0°C is approximately ___ m/s.
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound in air at 0°C is approximately 332 m/s. This value is calculated using the formula v = √(γP/ρ), where γ is the adiabatic index of air, P is the atmospheric pressure, and ρ is the density of air. At 0°C, this calculation gives the result of 332 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is a single numeric value of 332 m/s. However, the incorrect answer might come from using the wrong formula or not accounting for the temperature of 0°C. The speed of sound in air depends on the temperature, and at 0°C it is approximately 332 m/s, not a different value.

questions.question_text: In a standing wave on a string of length 2 m vibrating in its second harmonic, the number of nodes (including the endpoints) is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: In a standing wave on a string, the number of nodes (points with zero displacement) is one more than the number of the harmonic. Since the question states the string is vibrating in its second harmonic, the number of nodes (including the endpoints) is 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single integer. The correct number of nodes in a standing wave on a 2 m string vibrating in its second harmonic is 3. This is because the fundamental frequency (first harmonic) has 1 node at the midpoint, and each higher harmonic has 1 more node than the previous one. So the second harmonic will have 3 nodes - the two endpoints plus one additional node in the middle of the string.

questions.question_text: A sound wave of frequency 500 Hz travels in air at 340 m/s. Its wavelength is ___ m.
questions.explanation_correct: The wavelength of a wave is given by the formula v = fλ, where v is the wave speed, f is the frequency, and λ is the wavelength. Plugging in the values, we get λ = v/f = 340 m/s / 500 Hz = 0.68 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single decimal value in meters. The incorrect answer would be to not convert the units correctly or to use the wrong formula. For example, if you calculated the wavelength as 68 cm instead of 0.68 m, that would be an incorrect answer. The key is to correctly apply the formula v = fλ using the given values of wave speed and frequency.

questions.question_text: A source moving at 68 m/s towards a stationary observer emits sound at 500 Hz. The apparent frequency is ___ Hz (v = 340 m/s).
questions.explanation_correct: The apparent frequency increases due to the Doppler effect when the source is moving towards the observer. Using the Doppler shift formula, the apparent frequency is calculated as 625 Hz, which is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is a single number, 625 Hz. The incorrect answer may have resulted from not properly applying the Doppler shift formula, which states that the apparent frequency is given by f' = f(v+v_s)/(v-v_r), where f is the original frequency, v is the speed of sound, v_s is the speed of the source, and v_r is the speed of the receiver (observer). Plugging in the values given, the apparent frequency is calculated as 625 Hz.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following harmonics of a closed pipe (fundamental frequency f₁) in increasing order: (A) 1st harmonic (f₁), (B) 3rd harmonic (3f₁), (C) 5th harmonic (5f₁), (D) 7th harmonic (7f₁)
questions.explanation_correct: The harmonics of a closed pipe are all odd multiples of the fundamental frequency f₁, so the correct order is 1st harmonic (f₁), 3rd harmonic (3f₁), 5th harmonic (5f₁), and 7th harmonic (7f₁).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a closed pipe, the harmonics are given by the formula fₙ = nv/(4L), where n is an odd integer (1, 3, 5, 7, etc.). Since the frequencies increase linearly with the harmonic number n, the correct order of the harmonics is 1st, 3rd, 5th, and 7th, which correspond to f₁, 3f₁, 5f₁, and 7f₁, respectively.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following media in order of increasing speed of sound: (A) Air at 20°C, (B) Water at 20°C, (C) Steel, (D) Helium at 20°C
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound increases with the medium's stiffness and decreases with its density. Air has the lowest stiffness and density, so it has the lowest speed of sound. Helium has a lower density than air, so it has a higher speed of sound. Water has a higher stiffness and density than air and helium, so it has a higher speed of sound. Steel has the highest stiffness and density, so it has the highest speed of sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from lowest to highest speed of sound is: Air at 20°C, Helium at 20°C, Water at 20°C, Steel. This is because the speed of sound depends on the medium's properties like stiffness and density. Air has the lowest speed, followed by Helium which has a lower density than air. Water has a higher stiffness and density than air and Helium, so it has a higher speed of sound. Steel has the highest stiffness and density, so it has the highest speed of sound.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following scenarios by increasing apparent frequency heard by a stationary observer (source frequency = 500 Hz, v = 340 m/s): (A) Source at rest, (B) Source moving towards observer at 17 m/s, (C) Source moving away at 17 m/s, (D) Source moving towards observer at 34 m/s
questions.explanation_correct: The apparent frequency heard by a stationary observer increases as the source moves towards the observer, and decreases as the source moves away from the observer due to the Doppler effect. Therefore, the order from lowest to highest apparent frequency is: source moving away at 17 m/s, source at rest, source moving towards at 17 m/s, source moving towards at 34 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order is: source moving away at 17 m/s, source at rest, source moving towards at 17 m/s, source moving towards at 34 m/s. This is because the apparent frequency heard by the observer increases as the source moves towards the observer, and decreases as the source moves away. The higher the speed of the source, the greater the change in apparent frequency due to the Doppler effect.

questions.question_text: How does a transverse wave differ from a longitudinal wave in terms of particle vibration relative to wave propagation?

options.text: Both have particles vibrating along the direction of propagation
In transverse waves, particles vibrate perpendicular to propagation; in longitudinal waves, particles vibrate parallel to propagation
In transverse waves, particles vibrate parallel; in longitudinal waves, perpendicular
There is no difference in particle vibration

questions.explanation_correct: In transverse waves (e.g., waves on a string, light), particles oscillate perpendicular to the wave direction. In longitudinal waves (e.g., sound in air), particles oscillate parallel to the wave direction, creating compressions and rarefactions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The defining difference between transverse and longitudinal waves is the direction of particle vibration relative to wave propagation: perpendicular for transverse, parallel for longitudinal.

questions.question_text: How does the fundamental frequency of an open pipe differ from that of a closed pipe of the same length L?

options.text: Both have the same fundamental frequency
Open pipe: f = v/(2L); closed pipe: f = v/(4L) — the open pipe's fundamental is twice the closed pipe's
Closed pipe has a higher fundamental frequency
Open pipe: f = v/(4L); closed pipe: f = v/(2L)

questions.explanation_correct: Open pipe fundamental: f = v/(2L) (both ends are antinodes). Closed pipe fundamental: f = v/(4L) (one end is a node, other is antinode). The open pipe's fundamental is exactly twice the closed pipe's for the same length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open pipe fits half a wavelength in its length (λ = 2L), while a closed pipe fits a quarter wavelength (λ = 4L). This gives f_open = 2 × f_closed.

questions.question_text: How does the Doppler effect when the source approaches the observer differ from when the observer approaches the source?

options.text: Both produce exactly the same apparent frequency
Both produce a higher apparent frequency, but the formulas differ: f' = fv/(v − v_s) for moving source, and f' = f(v + v_o)/v for moving observer
Only the moving source produces a frequency shift
The moving observer produces a lower frequency

questions.explanation_correct: Both situations produce a higher apparent frequency, but the mathematical expressions differ. For a moving source approaching: f' = fv/(v − v_s). For a moving observer approaching: f' = f(v + v_o)/v. At low speeds these are approximately equal, but at higher speeds the results differ slightly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In sound, the Doppler effect depends on whether the source or observer is moving because the speed of sound is relative to the medium. Both approach scenarios increase frequency, but by different formulas.

questions.question_text: How does a progressive wave differ from a standing wave in terms of energy transfer?

options.text: Both transfer energy along the medium
A progressive wave transfers energy continuously; a standing wave has no net energy transfer along the medium
A standing wave transfers more energy than a progressive wave

questions.explanation_correct: A progressive (travelling) wave carries energy from one point to another through the medium. A standing wave, formed by superposition of two identical waves travelling in opposite directions, confines energy between nodes with no net energy transfer along the medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a standing wave, energy oscillates between kinetic and potential forms within each segment between nodes, but no net energy flows along the medium. A progressive wave continuously transports energy.

questions.question_text: How does the speed of sound in air at 0°C differ from the speed at 273°C?

options.text: Speed at 273°C is √2 times the speed at 0°C, because v ∝ √T and T doubles from 273 K to 546 K
Speed at 273°C is 4 times the speed at 0°C

questions.explanation_correct: v ∝ √T (absolute temperature). At 0°C, T = 273 K. At 273°C, T = 546 K = 2 × 273 K. So v₂/v₁ = √(546/273) = √2. The speed increases by a factor of √2 ≈ 1.414.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed of sound in a gas is proportional to the square root of absolute temperature. Doubling the absolute temperature (from 273 K to 546 K) increases the speed by √2, not by 2.

questions.question_text: A wave requires a material medium for propagation, produces compressions and rarefactions, and has particles vibrating along the direction of propagation. This wave is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The three clues — requires a medium (mechanical), produces compressions and rarefactions, and has particles vibrating along the propagation direction — all point to a longitudinal mechanical wave. Sound in air is the prime example.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electromagnetic waves don't need a medium. Transverse waves have perpendicular vibrations. Surface waves combine both. All clues point to a longitudinal mechanical wave.

questions.question_text: A wave pattern has fixed points of zero displacement and fixed points of maximum displacement. The pattern does not travel. This is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Fixed points of zero displacement (nodes) and fixed points of maximum displacement (antinodes) that do not travel are the defining features of a standing (stationary) wave, formed by superposition of two identical waves moving in opposite directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A progressive wave has crests and troughs that travel. A standing wave has fixed nodes and antinodes. The pattern not travelling is the key distinguishing feature.

questions.question_text: A pipe produces harmonics at frequencies f, 3f, 5f, 7f, ... (only odd multiples of the fundamental). This pipe is:

options.text: Closed pipe (open at one end, closed at the other)
An organ pipe open at both ends

questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe (closed at one end) produces only odd harmonics: f, 3f, 5f, 7f, ... This is because a node forms at the closed end and an antinode at the open end, allowing only odd multiples of the quarter-wavelength to fit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open pipe and a vibrating string produce all harmonics (f, 2f, 3f, ...). Only a closed pipe restricts to odd harmonics due to its boundary conditions.

questions.question_text: A listener hears a periodic rise and fall in loudness when two sound waves of nearly equal frequencies are played simultaneously. This phenomenon is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Beats occur when two waves of slightly different frequencies (f₁ and f₂) interfere, producing a periodic variation in amplitude (loudness) at the beat frequency |f₁ − f₂|. The periodic rise and fall of loudness is the hallmark of beats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Doppler effect changes pitch due to relative motion. Resonance amplifies at natural frequency. Echo is reflected sound. Periodic loudness variation from two close frequencies is beats.

questions.question_text: Riya plucks a guitar string of length 0.6 m and linear mass density 0.01 kg/m under tension 90 N. The fundamental frequency of the note she hears is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fundamental frequency of a string: f = √(T/μ)/(2L) = √(9000)/(1.2) = 94.87/1.2 ≈ 79.1 Hz.

questions.question_text: Amit blows across an open glass tube of length 0.425 m in the school lab and hears a musical note. Taking the speed of sound as 340 m/s, the fundamental frequency he hears is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Open pipe fundamental: f = v/(2L). The pipe length is 0.425 m, so f = 340/0.85 = 400 Hz. An open pipe produces all harmonics.

questions.question_text: Priya strikes two tuning forks in the school lab. One has frequency 512 Hz. She hears 6 beats per second. The possible frequency of the second tuning fork is:
questions.explanation_correct: Beat frequency = |f₁ − f₂|. Given 6 beats/s with one fork at 512 Hz: f₂ = 512 ± 6 = 506 Hz or 518 Hz. Without additional information, both values are possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Beats arise from the absolute difference of two frequencies. |512 − f₂| = 6 gives f₂ = 506 or 518 Hz. The beat frequency does not tell us which value is correct without further testing.

questions.question_text: Rohan, during a school science fair, demonstrates that the speed of sound in air increases with temperature. At 0°C the speed is 332 m/s. On a hot day at 35°C (308 K), the approximate speed of sound is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed of sound ∝ √T. At 35°C = 308 K: v = 332 × √(308/273) ≈ 332 × 1.062 ≈ 352 m/s. Temperature must be in kelvin.

questions.question_text: Meera sets up a standing wave on a 1.2 m string fixed at both ends, vibrating in its third harmonic. The distance between consecutive nodes is:
questions.explanation_correct: Third harmonic: L = 3(λ/2), so λ = 2L/3 = 2 × 1.2/3 = 0.8 m. Distance between consecutive nodes = λ/2 = 0.4 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In the third harmonic, three half-wavelengths fit in the string length. λ/2 = L/3 = 1.2/3 = 0.4 m is the distance between consecutive nodes.

questions.question_text: A closed pipe appears to produce the second harmonic (2f₁), just like an open pipe. However, this is actually:

options.text: True — closed pipes can produce all harmonics
False — closed pipes produce only odd harmonics (f, 3f, 5f...), so what seems like the 'second harmonic' does not exist in a closed pipe
True — but only at high temperatures
True — but only if the pipe is very long

questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe has a node at the closed end and an antinode at the open end. Only odd multiples of the quarter wavelength fit: f₁, 3f₁, 5f₁, ... The second harmonic (2f₁) cannot exist in a closed pipe. Students often assume all pipes produce all harmonics, which is a misconception.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The boundary conditions of a closed pipe (node at closed end, antinode at open end) allow only odd harmonics. Even harmonics are physically impossible for this geometry, regardless of temperature or length.

questions.question_text: Sound cannot travel through a vacuum. Which of the following seems like a medium but actually cannot transmit sound?

options.text: A perfect vacuum (even though it is very cold, like outer space)

questions.explanation_correct: Outer space is a near-perfect vacuum. Despite being a vast 'environment,' it contains essentially no particles for sound to propagate through. Students sometimes think sound can travel in space because of science fiction depictions. Water, steel, and air all have particles that can transmit sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound is a mechanical wave requiring a material medium. A vacuum, no matter how large, has no particles. Water, steel, and air are all valid media for sound propagation.

questions.question_text: Two identical sources approach a stationary observer from opposite directions at the same speed. Each emits frequency f₀. The observer expects to hear beats, but actually hears:

options.text: No beats, because both sources are Doppler-shifted by the same amount (both approaching gives f' = fv/(v − v_s) for each)
Very rapid beats at frequency f₀

questions.explanation_correct: Both sources approach the observer, so each is Doppler-shifted by the same formula: f' = f₀v/(v − v_s). Since both produce the same apparent frequency, the difference is zero, and no beats are heard. This surprises students who expect beats simply because there are two sources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Beats require two slightly different frequencies. Here, both sources approach from opposite sides at the same speed, producing identical Doppler-shifted frequencies. Beat frequency = |f₁' − f₂'| = 0.

questions.question_text: Why does the speed of sound in air increase with temperature?

options.text: Because air becomes denser at higher temperatures
Because higher temperature means higher molecular kinetic energy and faster molecular motion, which transmits the disturbance faster; mathematically v ∝ √T
Because pressure increases with temperature and v depends on pressure alone
Because humidity always increases with temperature

questions.explanation_correct: v = √(γRT/M), where T is absolute temperature. Higher T means greater average molecular kinetic energy, so molecules transfer the pressure disturbance (sound) more rapidly. The proportionality v ∝ √T explains the increase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air actually becomes less dense at higher temperature (at constant pressure). Pressure alone does not determine speed (v ∝ √(P/ρ), and both P and ρ change). The correct reason is the increase in molecular kinetic energy with temperature.

questions.question_text: Why is the distance between two consecutive nodes in a standing wave λ/2 and not λ?

options.text: Because nodes are always separated by one full wavelength
Because a standing wave is formed by superposition of two waves; the resultant has nodes at every half-wavelength interval since sin(kx) = 0 when kx = nπ, i.e., x = nλ/2
Because the wave speed is halved in a standing wave
Because the frequency doubles in a standing wave

questions.explanation_correct: When two identical waves y₁ = A sin(kx − ωt) and y₂ = A sin(kx + ωt) superpose, the result is y = 2A sin(kx) cos(ωt). Nodes occur where sin(kx) = 0, i.e., kx = nπ, giving x = nπ/k = nλ/2. Consecutive nodes are separated by λ/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sin(kx) spatial factor in a standing wave has zeros at x = nλ/2. This is a mathematical consequence of superposition. The wave speed and frequency do not change in a standing wave.

questions.question_text: Why does increasing the tension in a guitar string raise its pitch (fundamental frequency)?

options.text: Because higher tension makes the string longer
Because f = (1/2L)√(T/μ), so increasing tension T increases √T, which directly increases the frequency since L and μ remain constant
Because higher tension reduces the speed of waves on the string
Because higher tension changes the boundary conditions at the ends

questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental frequency f = (1/2L)√(T/μ). Wave speed v = √(T/μ) increases with tension. Since f = v/(2L) and L and μ are constant, higher v means higher f. Physically, tighter strings restore to equilibrium faster, increasing the oscillation rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Higher tension increases wave speed on the string (v = √(T/μ)), not decreases it. String length doesn't change when you tune. The formula directly shows f ∝ √T.
